title: 111_s2983
content: The "Hire Now Tax Cut Act of 2010" allows for payroll tax forgiveness for hiring unemployed workers. The "Hire Now Tax Cut Act of 2010" provides a special exemption for certain individuals hired in 2010, allowing qualified employers to not pay wages for services performed during that year. The exemption applies to employers other than the United States, any State, any local government, or any instrumentality of the foregoing. The "Hire Now Tax Cut Act of 2010" offers an exemption for individuals hired in 2010 by qualified employers, allowing them not to pay wages for services rendered that year. The exemption applies to employers other than the United States, any State, any local government, or any instrumentality of the foregoing. A qualified individual must meet specific criteria to be eligible for this exemption. The Hire Now Tax Cut Act of 2010 allows qualified employers to make an election not to include wages paid to qualified individuals in the 1-year period after hiring, in coordination with payroll tax forgiveness. Appropriations are made to the Federal Old-Age and Survivors Trust Fund to account for revenue reductions due to these amendments. The amendments made by the Hire Now Tax Cut Act of 2010 allow for transfers from the general fund to the Federal Old-Age and Survivors Trust Fund to replicate transfers that would have occurred without the amendments. The effective date for these amendments is after the enactment of the Act. SEC. 3. Business credit for retention of certain newly hired individuals in 2010. The current year business credit under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 will be increased by $1,000 for each retained worker who meets specific criteria. A retained worker is defined as a qualified individual employed by the taxpayer for at least 52 consecutive weeks with wages meeting certain requirements.
